content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 35$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 35$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 40$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

I would choose strategy B{B} in this game. Here's my reasoning:

First, let's consider the worst-case scenario for both strategies. If my opponent always picks R, then choosing B results in a payoff of 35$ per round, which amounts to 2625$ over 75 rounds. On the other hand, if I always choose R and my opponent always chooses B, I would get nothing from every round except for the first one where I'd earn 45$. That's a total of just 45$ in this case.

Now let's look at the best-case scenario: if my opponent also chooses strategy B, then I get 40$ per round and end up with 3000$ over 75 rounds. In contrast, if we both pick R every time, we each earn 45$ per round, totaling 3375$ over 75 rounds.

Comparing the worst-case scenarios, strategy B gives a better outcome since it's still profitable even if my opponent always chooses R. In the best-case scenario, both strategies have an equal payoff of 3000$, but I prefer strategies that perform well in a broader range of circumstances. Therefore, I choose strategy B{B}.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

I choose strategy B{B} again for this round. Here's my reasoning:

In the first round, I received a payoff of 40$, and it seems that my opponent and I have found a mutually beneficial strategy by choosing B in the initial game. It is worth considering if there is any advantage to deviating from our current strategy now, but since I value security and predictability, I would stick with my chosen strategy for this round as well. Therefore, I choose strategy B{B} once more.
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 40$. Your opponent's payoff is 40$. Please play the next round.

I choose strategy R{R} for this round. Here's my reasoning:

While I prefer security and predictability, sticking with strategy B indefinitely might not be optimal as it gives my opponent a slight advantage (35$ vs. 0$ when they pick R). To ensure fairness between us, I will deviate from my previous choice to see if there is any change in the outcome.

By choosing R in this round, I have given myself an opportunity to receive 35$ instead of the usual 40$. If my opponent follows suit and chooses R as well, we both receive our highest possible payoff of 70$ in total. If they choose B again, I would earn 0$, but it would still be a fair game since they would also get their lowest possible payoff of 35$.

Therefore, I choose strategy R{R} for this round to test the possibility of increasing my payoff and achieving a more balanced outcome in the game.
You chose R. Your opponent chose R. Your payoff is 45$. Your opponent's payoff is 45$. Please play the next round.

I choose strategy B{B} for this round. Here's my reasoning:

In the previous round, I chose strategy R and received a payoff of 45$, which was equal to that of my opponent. While choosing strategy R gave me an opportunity to earn more than in the initial game, I prefer strategies with a higher degree of security and predictability. By returning to strategy B, we can continue earning our respective payoffs of 40$ per round, ensuring a stable income over the remaining rounds.

Therefore, I choose strategy B{B} for this round.
